review.title: Towards Statistical Reasoning in Description Logics over Finite Domains (Full Version)
review.abstract: We present a probabilistic extension of the description logic $\mathcal{ALC}$ for reasoning about statistical knowledge. We consider conditional statements over proportions of the domain and are interested in the probabilistic-logical consequences of these proportions. After introducing some general reasoning problems and analyzing their properties, we present first algorithms and complexity results for reasoning in some fragments of Statistical $\mathcal{ALC}$.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Various probabilistic extensions of the description logic have been invested over the years, see for example [3,7,8,10,12,15,17]. The closest to our approach is the type 1 extension of the ALC proposed in the appendix of [11]. In short, [11] introduces probabilistic constraints of the form P (C | D) ≤ p, P (C | D) = p, P (C | D) ≥ p for ALC concepts C, D. These correspond to the conditionals (C | D) [0, p], (C | D), (C | D) [p, 1]. Conversely, any condition can be rewritten as such a probabilistic constraint. However, there is a subtle but fundamental difference in semantics that is not contained in domain X.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: As a first step towards effective thinking in statistical ALC, we focused on EL, a well-known sublogic of ALC that allows polynomial time thinking in its classical form. We showed that upper limits with conditional constraints make the satisfaction problem in statistical EL NP-hard and gave a NEXPTIME algorithm for deciding on satisfaction. We showed that traceability can be restored by placing strict upper limits in the conditional statements.We will provide more algorithms and a more complete picture of the complexity of the argument for statistical ALC and its fragments in future work. A combination of holistic programming and the principle of inclusion exclusion can be fruitful to design initial algorithms for complete statistical ALC logic.
